author: Torrent_Studios
title: Super rare minifigure in a cheap foil pack
review:
Introduction


391508 Bulkar was one of the foil packs I picked up from a LEGO Chima magazine.

I recently dug up my very small but substantial Chima collection to relive some of my childhood memories (which is an important part of my life now that I am in my teenage years).

I found this entire set unopened in one of my shelves, so of course I had to review it on Brickset - I just love reviewing lesser-known sets for people who just might be interested.

Packaging

The packaging is just a small rectangular foil bag, which is common packaging for magazine gifts that come with the Immediate Media LEGO magazine publishings. 

One small issue with this specific kind of packaging, is that the opening flap is always glued too tight to the pack, which is a bit of an issue for people who don't want to rip or crinkle the foil. If I'm patient, I take my time (about a minute or two) and carefully peel the flap, but sometimes I just whip out the scissors.

The art on the foil pack is pretty attractive, with age specifications, name of character included, and a "Limited Edition" label. (technically, the figure is limited edition, but only because all of the parts included have never been in this same configuration). Of course, there is also a beautiful Chima logo with an icy design on a fiery background, which contrasts really well.


There's also a nice CGI rendering of Bladvic (not Bulkar, but is a member of the Bear tribe and is close enough) and an image of the LEGO Bulkar minifigure. 

There is also a packaging art error here!!! On the foil pack, Bulkar is displayed with the normal pearl gold Chima armour, and I was pleasantly surprised to find out that he indeed came with the more sought-after peal gold heavy armour. This is a minor detail, albeit important.

Contents and Build

Bulkar is made up of six pieces: the aforementioned pearl gold heavy armour, a Fire Chi 1x1 trans-orange printed round tile, torso, legs, head and extended bear head piece.

His weapon has three pieces: a gold blade piece from LEGO Ninjago, a pearl gold shaft with cored knob, and a relatively rare flame blade piece that has not once been used outside of Chima. (which is a shame in my opinion, considering that this piece could be very useful)

Foil packs like these are usually gifts that come with LEGO magazines published by Immediate Media, and these packs usually don't come with instructions - the instructions would be included on pages of the magazine. Since this set is essentially just a minifigure, this is not much of an issue - it is very easy to build, even for the most inexperienced of beginners. (however this may be a bit of an issue for other similar foil packs like Star Wars ships and locations microbuilds)

It took me half a minute to put everything together, which is to be expected, but there really wasn't much of a process.

Minifigure

The Bulkar minifigure is quite rare, only appearing once in 70223 Icebite's Claw Driller, so I was very happy to acquire him in such a cheap set. Even now, this foil pack still goes for a reasonably affordable price on the aftermarket.

The figure has more than reasonable accessories - as I mentioned, the fire blade piece is now very rare so I am very happy to have got my first one in this set.

The printing on this figure is excellent too. It captures the most distinctive features of the Bear tribe. There is a wide streak of medium nougat fur across the torso where a bear's belly would be. A metallic gold chestplate design with Fire Chi plugged in adorns the front of the torso, which continues onto the back with a nice gold spine guard with brown straps. 

A nice dark brown pouch hangs from the chest plate on the right side of the figure with a small bee print, which I think represents honey that Bulkar carries with him. The hands are actually dark brown, which is different to the reddish brown of the torso. 

The legs have similarly detailed printing - metallic grey armour plates below dark bluish grey hips with intricate gold hexagonal patterns running across, not to mention realistic battle wear. There's also nice metallic gold knee pads with nice beehive symbols on them, and these have dark brown straps around them. There are also printed white claws on the feet. 

Streaks of fur are also positioned across the entire figure, giving some realistic detail, even on the extended head piece, which also has a medium nougat snout tip which contrasts well with all the reddish brown. 

Bulkar's head has two expressions, which are actually very similar and are only differentiated largely by the positioning of the eyebrows - one is a slightly happy face with a raised eyebrow, the other is a slight frown with level eyebrows. As good as these face prints are, I would have loved to see some more variation, for example a sleepy bear face.

To top this figure off, you can add on his pearl gold heavy armour with the 1x1 trans-orange printed round tile representing Fire Chi. You can also leave it off though, because the printing on the torso is more than good enough for display.

Playability

The playability that this set offers is extremely limited, but children would have fun swinging Bulkar around hitting invisible enemies or ones from their own collection. I would say that this minifigure would best fit in Chima Fire vs. Ice LEGO dioramas and MOCs.

Overall thoughts

391508 is a great foil pack with a very rare (and technically exclusive) minifigure from the long-retired Chima theme, and I would definitely recommend it to any fan of Chima - Bulkar is a great Bear to have among your ranks of Chima warriors.

Thank you for reading, I hope you found this review helpful and informative.
